overview_of_class: Geographic Information Systems (GIS) are computer systems that allow users to construct, visualize, and analyze geospatial data. While its use is trans-disciplinary, the course will focus on how to apply GIS techniques to important scientific questions in the environmental sciences. Specifically, students are introduced to exemplar problems in climate science, hydrology, geochemistry, and ecology that require geospatial analysis. Using these authentic scientific tasks as a motivational context, students learn the basic techniques for both acquiring and analyzing vector (i.e., points, lines, polygons) and raster (i.e., gridded) datasets. This includes spatial data acquired from field measurements using Global Positioning System (GPS), airborne / spaceborne remote sensing, and other mapping techniques. Data is primarily analyzed using the professional standard in GIS software - ArcGIS. However, instruction will be conducted such that skills can be readily extended to other GIS platforms. Furthermore, quantitative analyses in ArcGIS will be coordinated with analyses using other quantitative software (e.g., Matlab). Instruction will assume no prior experience using these specialized software packages. However, basic computer proficiency is expected of incoming students.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: ENVR SCI 201 or EARTH 201 or instructor permission

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Identify environmental problems suited to geospatial analysis; Analyze environmental data using a Geographical Information System (GIS); Integrate GIS analysis with other quantitative methods; Effectively communicate the results of geospatial analysis.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: The core teaching methods are lectures, supervised laboratory sessions, and mentored independent research. Class sessions last two and half hours and convene twice a week (~0:45 lecture; ~1:45 lab). However, students are expected to commit substantial time outside of class (>5 hours per week) to complete GIS projects and should plan accordingly. Classes strongly build off of each other. As such, completion of work during one week is contingent on completion of work from prior weeks.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: In-class exercises (15% total); homework exercises (16% total); three project reports (15% each), student-designed final project-written (16%); student-designed final project-oral (8%)

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Textbook: An Introduction to Geographical Information Systems / Ian Heywood, Sarah Cornelius, and Steve Carver / ISBN 978-0273722595/ 2010/ 4th ed. / Prentice Hall

overview_of_class: Are microbes important to the Earth System? Yes! This course will explore the fundamental controls on distribution, diversity, and activity of microbes across the Earth. We will focus on the dynamics within and between populations including ecological interactions between microbes and other microbes, higher organisms, and geochemical fluxes. The course will culminate in a survey of the ecology of microbe-rich environments on Earth today including the ocean, soils, the subsurface, extreme environments, and the human body!

overview_of_class:
Topic: Outer Solar System Satellites


This seminar examines the diverse satellites of Saturn and Jupiter. These worlds of fire and ice, young and old, split personalities, and relationships with planetary rings, have dramatically changed many of our ideas. We will cover their discovery and role in the history of sciences, physical characteristics, recent probes and findings, as well as theories for their evolution and tectonic activity. Also included, planning for future missions to outer solar system satellites to understand the formation of our solar system and additionally the search for life beyond the terrestrial planets. Recent results from Pluto will be highlighted in the seminar.
